context: Four boys—Fred, Juan, Marc, and Paul—and three girls—Nita, Rachel, and Trisha—will be assigned to a row of five adjacent lockers, numbered consecutively 1 through 5, arranged along a straight wall. The following conditions govern the assignment of lockers to the seven children: Each locker must be assigned to either one or two children, and each child must be assigned to exactly one locker. Each shared locker must be assigned to one girl and one boy. Juan must share a locker, but Rachel cannot share a locker. Nita's locker cannot be adjacent to Trisha's locker. Fred must be assigned to locker 3.
question: Which one of the following is a complete and accurate list of the children who must be among those assigned to shared lockers?
options: A) Fred, Juan
B) Juan, Paul
C) Juan, Marc, Paul
D) Juan, Marc, Trisha
E) Juan, Nita, Trisha
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
children = EnumSort([Fred, Juan, Marc, Paul, Nita, Rachel, Trisha])
lockers = EnumSort([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
assigned = Function([children, lockers] -> [bool])
shared = Function([children, lockers] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([c:children], Count([l:lockers], assigned(c, l)) == 1) ::: Each child must be assigned to exactly one locker
ForAll([l:lockers], Count([c:children], assigned(c, l)) == 1) ::: Each locker must be assigned to either one or two children
ForAll([l:lockers], Count([c:children], shared(c, l)) == 1) ::: Each shared locker must be assigned to one girl and one boy
And(assigned(Juan, l), Not(assigned(Rachel, l))) ::: Juan must share a locker, but Rachel cannot share a locker
ForAll([l:lockers], Implies(assigned(Nita, l), Not(assigned(Trisha, l)))) ::: Nita's locker cannot be adjacent to Trisha's locker
assigned(Fred, 3) ::: Fred must be assigned to locker 3

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following is a complete and accurate list of the children who must be among those assigned to shared lockers?
is_valid(ForAll([c:children], Or(c == Fred, c == Juan))) ::: (A)
is_valid(ForAll([c:children], Or(c == Juan, c == Paul))) ::: (B)
is_valid(ForAll([c:children], Or(c == Juan, c == Marc, c == Paul))) ::: (C)
is_valid(ForAll([c:children], Or(c == Juan, c == Marc, c == Trisha))) ::: (D)
is_valid(ForAll([c:children], Or(c == Juan, c == Nita, c == Trisha))) ::: (E)

Ingrid sits immediately next to, and immediately clockwise from, Olivia.

options: A) George, Peter, Karl, Fiona
B) Harriet, Olivia, Ingrid, Karl
C) Ingrid, Fiona, Peter, Manuel
D) Olivia, Manuel, Karl, George
E) Peter, Harriet, Karl, Fiona

ForAll([p:people], Count([s:seats], seated(p, s)) == 1)

# Constraints
And(seated(Fiona, s1), seated(George, s2), s1!= s2, s1 < s2, s2 - s1 == 3) ::: Fiona sits directly across from George
And(seated(Harriet, s1), seated(Karl, s2), s1!= s2, s1 < s2, s2 - s1!= 3) ::: Harriet sits immediately next to neither Fiona nor Karl
And(seated(Ingrid, s1), seated(Olivia, s2), s1!= s2, s1 < s2, s2 - s1 == 1) ::: Ingrid sits immediately next to, and immediately clockwise from, Olivia

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following could be the order in which four of the people are seated, with no one else seated between them, counting clockwise around the table?
is_sat(And(seated(George, 1), seated(Peter, 2), seated(Karl, 3), seated(Fiona, 4))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(seated(Harriet, 1), seated(Olivia, 2), seated(Ingrid, 3), seated(Karl, 4))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(seated(Ingrid, 1), seated(Fiona, 2), seated(Peter, 3), seated(Manuel, 4))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(seated(Olivia, 1), seated(Manuel, 2), seated(Karl, 3), seated(George, 4))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(seated(Peter, 1), seated(Harriet, 2), seated(Karl, 3), seated(Fiona, 4))) ::: (E)

Six sections—Fantasy, Hobbies, Music, Puzzles, Reading, and Science—will each be confined to exactly one aisle, with each aisle containing at least one of the sections. The following conditions hold: Reading must be located in the same aisle as either Fantasy or Music. Fantasy must be located in a lower-numbered aisle than both Music and Puzzles. Science must be located in a lower-numbered aisle than Puzzles. Science cannot be located in a lower-numbered aisle than Hobbies.
question: Which one of the following CANNOT be the list of the sections located in aisle 2?
options: A) Hobbies, Music
B) Music, Reading
C) Music, Science
D) Hobbies, Music, Science
E) Music, Reading, Science
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
aisles = EnumSort([1, 2, 3])
sections = EnumSort([Fantasy, Hobbies, Music, Puzzles, Reading, Science])
locations = Function([aisles, sections] -> [aisles])

# Constraints
ForAll([s:sections], Count([a:aisles], locations(a, s)) == 1) ::: each section is confined to exactly one aisle
And(locations(a, Reading) == locations(a, Fantasy), locations(a, Reading) == locations(a, Music)) ::: Reading must be located in the same aisle as either Fantasy or Music
And(locations(a, Fantasy) < locations(a, Music), locations(a, Fantasy) < locations(a, Puzzles)) ::: Fantasy must be located in a lower-numbered aisle than both Music and Puzzles
locations(a, Science) < locations(a, Puzzles) ::: Science must be located in a lower-numbered aisle than Puzzles
Not(And(locations(a, Science) < locations(a, Hobbies), locations(a, Science) < locations(a, Music))) ::: Science cannot be located in a lower-numbered aisle than Hobbies

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following CANNOT be the list of the sections located in aisle 2?
is_exception(is_sat(ForAll([s:sections], locations(2, s) == [Hobbies, Music]))) ::: (A)
is_exception(is_sat(ForAll([s:sections], locations(2, s) == [Music, Reading]))) ::: (B)
is_exception(is_sat(ForAll([s:sections], locations(2, s) == [Music, Science]))) ::: (C)
is_exception(is_sat(ForAll([s:sections], locations(2, s) == [Hobbies, Music, Science]))) ::: (D)
is_exception(is_sat(ForAll([s:sections], locations(2, s) == [Music, Reading, Science]))) ::: (E)

context: Millville has created three new development zones: Z1, Z2, and Z3. Within these zones, subzones can be designated for housing, industrial, or retail use, with no subzone designated for more than one use. By city regulation, a total of no more than three subzones can be designated for each of the three uses. The following restrictions are in place: Retail subzones are not allowed in Z1. No more than two subzones for housing are allowed in any particular zone. No more than one retail subzone is allowed in any zone in which a subzone is designated for housing. Industrial subzones are not allowed in any zone in which a subzone is designated for housing or three subzones are designated for retail use.
question: Which one of the following is an allowable way of designating subzones within the three zones?
options: A) Z1: no designated subzones Z2: one housing subzone, two retail subzones Z3: one industrial subzone, one retail subzone
B) Z1: one housing subzone, one industrial subzone Z2: two housing subzones, one retail subzone Z3: one industrial subzone, one retail subzone
C) Z1: one housing subzone, one retail subzone Z2: two housing subzones, one retail subzone Z3: one industrial subzone, one retail subzone
D) Z1: one industrial subzone Z2: three housing subzones Z3: three retail subzones
E) Z1: one industrial subzone Z2: two housing subzones, one retail subzone Z3: one industrial subzone, two retail subzones
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
zones = EnumSort([Z1, Z2, Z3])
subzones = EnumSort([housing, industrial, retail])
designated = Function([zones, subzones] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([z:zones], Count([s:subzones], designated(z, s)) <= 3) ::: a total of no more than three subzones can be designated for each of the three uses
Not(designated(Z1, retail)) ::: Retail subzones are not allowed in Z1
ForAll([z:zones], Count([s:subzones], designated(z, s) == housing) <= 2) ::: No more than two subzones for housing are allowed in any particular zone
ForAll([z:zones], Implies(designated(z, housing), Not(designated(z, retail)))) ::: No more than one retail subzone is allowed in any zone in which a subzone is designated for housing
ForAll([z:zones], Implies(designated(z, housing), Not(designated(z, industrial)))) ::: Industrial subzones are not allowed in any zone in which a subzone is designated for housing
ForAll([z:zones], Implies(Count([s:subzones], designated(z, s) == retail) == 3, Not(designated(z, industrial)))) ::: Industrial subzones are not allowed in any zone in which a subzone is designated for housing

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following is an allowable way of designating subzones within the three zones?
is_sat(And(designated(Z1, housing), designated(Z2, housing), designated(Z2, retail), designated(Z3, industrial), designated(Z3, retail))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(designated(Z1, housing), designated(Z1, industrial), designated(Z2, housing), designated(Z2, retail), designated(Z3, industrial), designated(Z3, retail))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(designated(Z1, housing), designated(Z1, retail), designated(Z2, housing), designated(Z2, retail), designated(Z3, industrial), designated(Z3, retail))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(designated(Z1, industrial), designated(Z2, housing), designated(Z2, housing), designated(Z2, housing), designated(Z3, retail), designated(Z3, retail), designated(Z3, retail))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(designated(Z1, industrial), designated(Z2, housing), designated(Z2, retail), designated(Z3, industrial), designated(Z3, retail), designated(Z3, retail))) ::: (E)

context: A researcher is studying seven manuscripts—F, G, H, L, M, P, and S—to determine their relative ages. It is known that no two manuscripts were written at the same time. The researcher has also determined the following: H was written earlier than S but later than F. P was the next manuscript written after G. At least four of the manuscripts were written earlier than L. At least four of the manuscripts were written later than M. H was not written fifth.
question: Which one of the following could be the order in which the manuscripts were written, from first to last?
options: A) F, M, G, H, P, L, S
B) G, P, M, F, H, S, L
C) H, F, M, G, P, L, S
D) L, F, M, G, P, H, S
E) M, F, H, S, L, G, P
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
manuscripts = EnumSort([F, G, H, L, M, P, S])
written = Function([manuscripts] -> [int])
ForAll([m:manuscripts], And(1 <= written(m), written(m) <= 7))

# Constraints
Distinct([m:manuscripts], written(m)) ::: no two manuscripts were written at the same time

The schedule of speeches is constrained by the following: Molina's speech must be earlier than Long's, and in the same room. Neither Xiao's speech nor Yoshida's speech can be earlier than Zimmerman's. If Long's speech is in the Gold Room, then Xiao's and Zimmerman's speeches must both be in the Rose Room.
question: Which one of the following could be a complete and accurate list of the speeches given in the Gold Room, in the order in which they occur?
options: A) Long's, Molina's
B) Molina's, Yoshida's
C) Molina's, Yoshida's, Long's
D) Yoshida's, Zimmerman's, Xiao's
E) Zimmerman's, Molina's, Long's
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
speakers = EnumSort([Long, Molina, Xiao, Yoshida, Zimmerman])
rooms = EnumSort([Gold, Rose])
times = EnumSort([1, 2, 3])
speeches = Function([speakers, rooms, times] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([s:speakers], Count([r:rooms, t:times], speeches(s, r, t)) == 1) ::: Each speaker will give exactly one speech
ForAll([r:rooms], Count([t:times], speeches(_, r, t)) == 3) ::: In each room, there will be exactly one speech at 1 P.M. and one speech at 2 P.M.
And(speeches(Molina, r, t), speeches(Long, r, t)) ::: Molina's speech must be earlier than Long's, and in the same room
And(speeches(Xiao, r, t), speeches(Yoshida, r, t)) ::: Neither Xiao's speech nor Yoshida's speech can be earlier than Zimmerman's
And(speeches(Long, Gold, t), Not(speeches(Xiao, Gold, t)), Not(speeches(Zimmerman, Gold, t))) ::: If Long's speech is in the Gold Room, then Xiao's and Zimmerman's speeches must both be in the Rose Room

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following could be a complete and accurate list of the speeches given in the Gold Room, in the order in which they occur?
is_sat(And(speeches(Long, Gold, 1), speeches(Molina, Gold, 2))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(speeches(Molina, Gold, 1), speeches(Yoshida, Gold, 2))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(speeches(Molina, Gold, 1), speeches(Yoshida, Gold, 2), speeches(Long, Gold, 3))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(speeches(Yoshida, Gold, 1), speeches(Zimmerman, Gold, 2), speeches(Xiao, Gold, 3))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(speeches(Zimmerman, Gold, 1), speeches(Molina, Gold, 2), speeches(Long, Gold, 3))) ::: (E)
------

context: At a business symposium there will be exactly five speakers: Long, Molina, Xiao, Yoshida, and Zimmerman. Each speaker will give exactly one speech, in either the Gold Room or the Rose Room. In each room, there will be exactly one speech at 1 P.M. and one speech at 2 P.M. In one of the rooms, yet to be determined, there will also be a speech at 3 P.M. Neither Xiao's speech nor Yoshida's speech can be earlier than Zimmerman's. If Long's speech is in the Gold Room, then Xiao's and Zimmerman's speeches must both be in the Rose Room.
question: Which one of the following, if substituted for the constraint that neither Xiao's speech nor Yoshida's speech can be earlier than Zimmerman's, would have the same effect in determining the schedule of speeches with regard to rooms and times?
options: A) Long's speech must be at 3 P.M.
B) Molina's speech cannot be earlier than Zimmerman's.
C) Either Xiao's speech or Yoshida's speech must be after Zimmerman's.
D) Either Xiao's speech or Yoshida's speech or both must be at 2 P.M.
E) Zimmerman's speech must be at 1 P.M.
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
speakers = EnumSort([Long, Molina, Xiao, Yoshida, Zimmerman])
rooms = EnumSort([Gold, Rose])
times = EnumSort([1, 2, 3])
speeches = Function([speakers, rooms, times] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([s:speakers], Count([r:rooms, t:times], speeches(s, r, t)) == 1) ::: Each speaker will give exactly one speech
ForAll([r:rooms], Count([t:times], speeches(_, r, t)) == 2) ::: In each room, there will be exactly one speech at 1 P.M. and one speech at 2 P.M.
ForAll([r:rooms], Count([t:times], speeches(_, r, t)) == 3) ::: In one of the rooms, yet to be determined, there will also be a speech at 3 P.M.
And(speeches(Molina, _, _), speeches(Long, _, _)) ::: Molina's speech must be earlier than Long's, and in the same room
And(speeches(Xiao, _, _), speeches(Yoshida, _, _)) ::: Neither Xiao's speech nor Yoshida's speech can be earlier than Zimmerman's
And(speeches(Long, Gold, _), And(speeches(Xiao, Rose, _), speeches(Zimmerman, Rose, _))) ::: If Long's speech is in the Gold Room, then Xiao's and Zimmerman's speeches must both be in the Rose Room

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following, if substituted for the constraint that neither Xiao's speech nor Yoshida's speech can be earlier than Zimmerman's, would have the same effect in determining the schedule of speeches with regard to rooms and times?
is_sat(ForAll([s:speakers], speeches(s, Gold, 3))) ::: (A)
is_sat(ForAll([s:speakers], Implies(speeches(Molina, _, _), speeches(s, _, _)))) ::: (B)
is_sat(ForAll([s:speakers], Or(speeches(Xiao, _, _), speeches(Yoshida, _, _)))) ::: (C)
is_sat(ForAll([s:speakers], Or(speeches(Xiao, _, 2), speeches(Yoshida, _, 2)))) ::: (D)
is_sat(ForAll([s:speakers], speeches(s, _, 1))) ::: (E)
------

context: During the seventeenth century, three families—the Trents, the Williamses, and the Yandells—owned the five buildings that constituted the center of their village—the forge, the granary, the inn, the mill, and the stable. Each family owned at least one of the buildings and each building was owned by exactly one of the families. The historical evidence establishes the following about the ownership of the buildings: The Williamses owned more of the buildings than the Yandells owned. Neither the inn nor the mill belonged to the owner of the forge. Either the Trents owned the stable or the Yandells owned the inn, or both.
question: Which one of the following could be an accurate matching of each family to the building or buildings it owned?
options: A) Trents: the granary, the stable Williamses: the inn, the mill Yandells: the forge
B) Trents: the granary, the mill Williamses: the inn, the stable Yandells: the forge
C) Trents: the forge, the mill Williamses: the granary, the stable Yandells: the inn
D) Trents: the forge, the granary Williamses: the mill Yandells: the inn, the stable
E) Trents: the stable Williamses: the inn, the mill Yandells: the forge, the granary
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
families = EnumSort([Trents, Williamses, Yandells])
buildings = EnumSort([forge, granary, inn, mill, stable])
owns = Function([families, buildings] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([f:families], Count([b:buildings], owns(f, b)) >= 1) ::: Each family owned at least one of the buildings
Count([b:buildings], owns(Williamses, b)) > Count([b:buildings], owns(Yandells, b)) ::: The Williamses owned more of the buildings than the Yandells owned
Not(And(owns(forge, f), owns(inn, f), owns(mill, f))) ::: Neither the inn nor the mill belonged to the owner of the forge
Or(And(owns(stable, Trents), owns(inn, Yandells)), And(owns(stable, Trents), owns(inn, Yandells))) ::: Either the Trents owned the stable or the Yandells owned the inn, or both

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following could be an accurate matching of each family to the building or buildings it owned?
is_sat(And(owns(Trents, granary), owns(Trents, stable), owns(Williamses, inn), owns(Williamses, mill), owns(Yandells, forge))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(owns(Trents, granary), owns(Trents, mill), owns(Williamses, inn), owns(Williamses, stable), owns(Yandells, forge))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(owns(Trents, forge), owns(Trents, mill), owns(Williamses, granary), owns(Williamses, stable), owns(Yandells, inn))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(owns(Trents, forge), owns(Trents, granary), owns(Williamses, mill), owns(Yandells, inn), owns(Yandells, stable))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(owns(Trents, stable), owns(Williamses, inn), owns(Williamses, mill), owns(Yandells, forge), owns(Yandells, granary))) ::: (E)
------

context: A florist is filling a customer's order for three bouquets—bouquet 1, bouquet 2, and bouquet 3. Each of the bouquets is to be composed of one or more of five kinds of flowers—lilies, peonies, roses, snapdragons, and tulips—subject to the following conditions: Bouquets 1 and 3 cannot have any kind of flower in common. Bouquets 2 and 3 must have exactly two kinds of flowers in common. Bouquet 3 must have snapdragons. If a bouquet has lilies, that bouquet must also have roses but cannot have snapdragons. If a bouquet has tulips, that bouquet must also have peonies.
question: Which one of the following could be a complete and accurate list of the kinds of flowers in each of the bouquets?
options: A) bouquet 1: lilies, roses bouquet 2: peonies, roses, tulips bouquet 3: peonies, snapdragons, tulips
B) bouquet 1: peonies, roses bouquet 2: peonies, snapdragons bouquet 3: peonies, snapdragons, tulips
C) bouquet 1: peonies, tulips bouquet 2: roses, snapdragons, tulips bouquet 3: roses, snapdragons
D) bouquet 1: roses bouquet 2: peonies, snapdragons bouquet 3: lilies, peonies, snapdragons
E) bouquet 1: snapdragons bouquet 2: lilies, roses bouquet 3: lilies, roses
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
bouquets = EnumSort([bouquet_1, bouquet_2, bouquet_3])
flowers = EnumSort([lilies, peonies, roses, snapdragons, tulips])
has = Function([bouquets, flowers] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([b:bouquets], Count([f:flowers], has(b, f)) >= 1) ::: each bouquet has at least one kind of flower
And(has(bouquet_1, lilies), has(bouquet_1, roses)) ::: If a bouquet has lilies, that bouquet must also have roses
And(has(bouquet_1, snapdragons), Not(has(bouquet_1, lilies))) ::: If a bouquet has snapdragons, that bouquet cannot have lilies
And(has(bouquet_1, lilies), Not(has(bouquet_2, lilies))) ::: Bouquets 1 and 3 cannot have any kind of flower in common
And(has(bouquet_2, peonies), has(bouquet_2, roses)) ::: If a bouquet has peonies, that bouquet must also have roses
And(has(bouquet_2, tulips), has(bouquet_2, peonies)) ::: If a bouquet has tulips, that bouquet must also have peonies
And(has(bouquet_3, snapdragons), has(bouquet_3, lilies)) ::: Bouquet 3 must have snapdragons
And(has(bouquet_2, snapdragons), has(bouquet_2, tulips)) ::: Bouquets 2 and 3 must have exactly two kinds of flowers in common

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following could be a complete and accurate list of the kinds of flowers in each of the bouquets?
is_sat(And(has(bouquet_1, lilies), has(bouquet_1, roses), has(bouquet_2, peonies), has(bouquet_2, roses), has(bouquet_2, tulips), has(bouquet_3, peonies), has(bouquet_3, snapdragons), has(bouquet_3, tulips))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(has(bouquet_1, peonies), has(bouquet_1, roses), has(bouquet_2, peonies), has(bouquet_2, snapdragons), has(bouquet_3, peonies), has(bouquet_3, snapdragons), has(bouquet_3, tulips))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(has(bouquet_1, peonies), has(bouquet_1, tulips), has(bouquet_2, roses), has(bouquet_2, snapdragons), has(bouquet_2, tulips), has(bouquet_3, roses), has(bouquet_3, snapdragons))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(has(bouquet_1, roses), has(bouquet_2, peonies), has(bouquet_2, snapdragons), has(bouquet_3, lilies), has(bouquet_3, peonies), has(bouquet_3, snapdragons))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(has(bouquet_1, snapdragons), has(bouquet_2, lilies), has(bouquet_2, roses), has(bouquet_3, lilies), has(bouquet_3, roses))) ::: (E)
------

More trees are planted on lot 3 than on lot 1.
question: Which one of the following could be the list of the trees that the landscaper plants on each of the lots today?

D) lot 1: the sycamore, the walnut lot 2: the larch, the maple lot 3: the hickory, the oak, the plum
E) lot 1: the walnut lot 2: the plum, the sycamore lot 3: the hickory, the maple, the oak

# Declarations
trees = EnumSort([hickory, larch, maple, oak, plum, sycamore, walnut])
lots = EnumSort([1, 2, 3])
planted = Function([trees, lots] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([t:trees], Count([l:lots], planted(t, l)) == 1) ::: Each tree must be planted on exactly one of three lots
And(planted(hickory, l), planted(oak, l), planted(t, l)) ::: The trees planted on one lot are the hickory, the oak, and exactly one other tree

Count([t:trees], planted(t, 3)) > Count([t:trees], planted(t, 1)) ::: More trees are planted on lot 3 than on lot 1

is_sat(And(planted(larch, 1), planted(maple, 1), planted(walnut, 1), planted(hickory, 2), planted(oak, 2), planted(plum, 2), planted(sycamore, 3), planted(walnut, 3))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(planted(larch, 1), planted(maple, 1), planted(walnut, 1), planted(hickory, 2), planted(oak, 2), planted(walnut, 2), planted(plum, 3), planted(sycamore, 3))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(planted(maple, 1), planted(hickory, 2), planted(larch, 2), planted(oak, 2), planted(plum, 3), planted(sycamore, 3), planted(walnut, 3))) ::: (C)

context: Each issue of a business newsletter has five slots, numbered 1 through 5. The policy of the newsletter requires that there are at least three features per issue, with each feature completely occupying one or more of the slots. Each feature can be one of four types—finance, industry, marketing, or technology. Any slot not containing a feature contains a graphic. The newsletters policy further requires that each issue be structured as follows: Any feature occupying more than one slot must occupy consecutively numbered slots. If an issue has any finance or technology feature, then a finance or technology feature must occupy slot 1. An issue can have at most one industry feature.
question: Which one of the following is an allowable structure for an issue of the newsletter?
options: A) slot 1: a finance feature; slot 2: an industry feature; slot 3: a second industry feature; slot 4: a graphic; slot 5: a graphic
B) slot 1: a graphic; slot 2: a technology feature; slot 3: a second technology feature; slot 4: a graphic; slot 5: a third technology feature
C) slots 1 and 2: a single industry feature; slots 3 and 4: a single marketing feature; slot 5: a finance feature
D) slot 1: a technology feature; slots 2 and 3: a single industry feature; slot 4: a finance feature; slot 5: a graphic
E) slot 1: a technology feature; slots 2 and 4: a single marketing feature; slot 3: an industry feature; slot 5: a graphic

ForAll([s:slots], Count([f:features], occupies(s, f)) >= 3) ::: there are at least three features per issue

ForAll([s:slots], Implies(occupies(s, industry), Not(occupies(s, industry)))) ::: An issue can have at most one industry feature
